qas.question: Since when have inexpensive ceramic disc capacitors existed?
Since when have surface mount packages for capacitors been commonly in use?
What do surface mount packages lack that allows their use on the surface of printed circuit boards?
What is one benefit of using surface mount components?
What is one difficulty when using surface mount components?

answers.text: manual handling is made difficult due to their small size

plausible_answers.text: Small, cheap discoidal ceramic capacitors have existed

qas.question: What has been in use since the 1990s?
What do surface mount packages have that allows their use on the surface of printed circuit boards?
What is one inconvenience of using surface mount components?
What is one easy part when using surface mount components?

context: <b5_0>Small, cheap discoidal ceramic capacitors have existed<b5_0/> since <a0_0>the 1930s<a0_0/>, and remain in widespread use. Since <a1_0>the 1980s<a1_0/>, <b6_0>surface mount packages for capacitors<b6_0/> have been widely used. These packages are extremely small and lack <a2_0><b7_0>connecting leads<b7_0/><a2_0/>, allowing them to be soldered directly onto the surface of printed circuit boards. Surface mount components avoid undesirable high-frequency effects due to the leads and <a3_0><b8_0>simplify automated assembly<b8_0/><a3_0/>, although <a4_0><b9_0>manual handling<b9_0/> is made difficult due to their small size<a4_0/>.
